Award.AwardTitle: The LIFE Center: Learning in Informal and Formal Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal NSF 0835854: The LIFE Center
ABSTRACT

This is a proposal to renew the LIFE Center, situated at the University of Washington in Seattle, a multi-university, multi-year, interdisciplinary project devoted to the study of social factors in learning, an underappreciated element of the science of learning. Now concluding its 5th year of support, the center proposes to continue its efforts "to develop and test principles about the social foundations of human learning in informal and formal environments, including how people learn to innovate in contemporary society, with the goal of enhancing human learning from infancy to adulthood."

Among the research projects to be pursued during the next phase of investigation are (1) social factors in language learning--especially in infants, (2) new designs to enhance learning via media and technology by identifying and utilizing social interaction and "social belief", the perception that one is interacting with a human being, whether or not this is true, (3) effects on learning of social identity and stereotyping, (4) social practices in science learning, including an anthropological study of informal science learning in social settings, (5) new views of and efforts to enhance expertise, transfer and assessment, (6) social practices in the workplace that foster learning, and (7) the importance of informal teaching by parents, peers and mentors.

In addition to demonstrating strong effects of social factors on learning, the researchers in LIFE will pursue answers to the overall theoretical question: "What is it about the social that powerfully enhances learning?"

More than just a research center, LIFE participants are also committed to the education of undergraduates, graduate students and post-docs; to increasing diversity among faculty, students and future scientists; and to the transfer of research results to practice in education and workplaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The LIFE (Learning in Informal and Formal Environments) Center, founded in 2004, united scientists, graduate students and post-doctoral fellows from the University of Washington’s (UW) Institute for Learning & Brain Sciences (I-LABS), UW College of Education, Stanford University, and Stanford Research International, Berkeley, and Northwestern. The LIFE Center completed its 10-year funding cycle, plus an additional two no-cost extension years, in February of 2017. Patricia K. Kuhl (UW I-LABS) served as LIFE Center Director from 2008 to 2017; John Bransford directed from the Center from 2004 to 2007.

Intellectual Merit

The theme of LIFE’s work was the social foundations of learning. LIFE investigated the idea that the social contexts in which humans learn, and the social interactions that form the basis for the transfer of learning from one generation to the next, rely on the key principle that humans have an innate drive and are rewarded by learning from others. This key principle was investigated through research that utilized many approaches – from experimental studies that measured human behaviors in and out of social contexts and with or without social interaction, to studies that measured the human brain’s response to social signals versus nonsocial signals. Our research extended to ethnographic and videographic assessments in the field, in homes and schools, and in out-of-school settings where children learn. Our examinations revealed the power and the diverse effects of social contexts and social interactions that support learning. Importantly, LIFE Center research was conducted over the lifespan. Our work demonstrated that at all ages—early in infancy, in the early school grades, throughout middle school, in high school, as well as in adulthood, social learning is powerful and ubiquitous.

The LIFE Center’s research had transformative impact in four areas: (a) early learning and brain and behavioral measures of development, (b) social learning from technology, (c) the role of identity in learning, and (d) bridging learning in informal and formal settings. Work in several of these areas – especially the work on early learning and brain measures of development – led to a sea change in the United States policymakers’ thinking about the preparation children need to be ready for school, and what became known as the “preparation gap” in many children growing up in poverty without access to early educational opportunities. LIFE’s presentations at three Obama White House conferences: early learning, bilingualism, science-technology-engineering-math (STEM) learning, brought attention to LIFE’s portfolio of research and its evidence-based interventions. Numerous foundations and philanthropic groups in the United States and worldwide cite the research of one of the LIFE Center’s units, I-LABS, as providing a driving force behind their efforts and a powerful catayst for change. Multiple school-based projects and partnerships developed between LIFE Center investigators and school systems, highly innovative interventions were tested, educational tools and products were developed, and schools’ philosophies about the role of social interaction in learning were altered, contributing to an understanding of how “social” technologies for learning can capitalize on humans’ drive for social interaction while learning from screens and social media.

The LIFE Center’s diagram, illustrating the percentage of time learners spend in as opposed to out of school, has been downloaded over 150,000 times (Figure 1). The diagram was published in a volume entitled, Life-long, Life-wide, and Life-deep, which addressed diversity in learning and led to the LIFE’s Center’s highly successful line of work on the role of a learners’ identity on the aspirations of students. 

The LIFE Center produced 561 directly supported publications, and an additional 240 publications related to LIFE Center work. We trained a next-generation of scientists and educators by producing 123 PhD students and 51 post-doctoral fellows. LIFE’s students and fellows now work in academia, industry, business, and government.

Broader Impacts

Broader LIFE Center impacts include our 1,604 keynote addresses including to: World Bank, Vatican’s Pontifical Academy of Sciences, Aspen Ideas Festival, Charlie Rose Brain Series on PBS, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), Obama’s 2014 White House Conference on Early Educational Opportunities, UNESCO, Congressional Briefings, Education Nation, Kuhl’s TED Talk viewed > 2.5M times. Director Kuhl addressed the National Commission on Social, Emotional, and Academic Development in 2016, led by Linda Darling Hammond, President and CEO of the Learning Policy Institute. The Commission’s goal is to ensure that all K-12 institutions address students’ social and emotional developmental needs as a critical part of their academic success. Kuhl’s presentation, “The social brain as the ‘gateway’ to cognitive learning” led Commission members to request her help on developing materials for wide dissemination to education professionals and policymakers to focus their attention on social factors in learning and their implications for education and society.
